hu.elte.txtuml.api

Class ModelExecutor.Settings

  • java.lang.Object
    • hu.elte.txtuml.api.ModelExecutor.Settings
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ModelElement
    Enclosing class:
    ModelExecutor

    public static final class ModelExecutor.Settings
extends java.lang.Object
implements ModelElement
    Provides all the global settings of txtUML model execution through its static methods.

    Represents: no model element

    Usage:

    Calling its static methods only affect the model execution, they are not exported to EMF-UML2.

    Its static methods might be called from anywhere in the model as they are not harmful to the model execution in any way. However, it is strongly advised to perform any changes in the settings before the model execution is started to prevent confusing and unexpected results.

    Java restrictions:

    • Instantiate: disallowed
    • Define subtype: disallowed

    See the documentation of Model for an overview on modeling in txtUML.

    Author:
    Gabor Ferenc Kovacs

    • Method Detail

      • setUserOutStream

        public static void setUserOutStream(java.io.PrintStream userOutStream)
        Sets the stream on which the user's non-error log is printed. The user may write non-error log any time during model execution by calling the log method of the action language.

        By default, user's non-error log is printed on System.out.

        Parameters:
        userOutStream - the stream on which the user's non-error log will be printed in the future

      • setUserErrorStream

        public static void setUserErrorStream(java.io.PrintStream userErrorStream)
        Sets the stream on which the user's error log is printed. The user may write error log any time during model execution by calling the logError method of the action language.

        By default, user's error log is printed on System.err.

        Parameters:
        userErrorStream - the stream on which the user's error log will be printed in the future

      • setExecutorOutStream

        public static void setExecutorOutStream(java.io.PrintStream executorOutStream)
        Sets the stream on which the executor's non-error log is printed. Executor's non-error log consists of short messages reporting about certain changes in the runtime model, like a model object processing a signal or using a transition. Executor's non-error log can be turned on or off by calling the setExecutorLog method.

        By default, executor's non-error log is printed on System.out.

        Parameters:
        executorOutStream - the stream on which the executor's non-error log will be printed in the future

      • setExecutorErrorStream

        public static void setExecutorErrorStream(java.io.PrintStream executorErrorStream)
        Sets the stream on which the executor's error log is printed. Executor's error log consists of runtime errors and warnings.

        By default, executor's error log is printed on System.err.

        Parameters:
        executorErrorStream - the stream on which the executor's error log will be printed in the future

      • setExecutorLog

        public static void setExecutorLog(boolean newValue)
        Sets whether executor's non-error log has to be shown. By default, it is switched off.

        Executor's non-error log consists of short messages reporting about certain changes in the runtime model, like a model object processing a signal or using a transition.

        Parameters:
        newValue - whether executor's non-error log has to shown

      • setDynamicChecks

        public static void setDynamicChecks(boolean newValue)
        Sets whether optional dynamic checks should be performed during model execution. These checks include checking lower bounds of multiplicities, checking whether the guards of two transitions from the same vertex are overlapping, etc.

        These checks are performed by default.

        Parameters:
        newValue - whether optional dynamic checks should be performed

      • setExecutionTimeMultiplier

        public static void setExecutionTimeMultiplier(float newMultiplier)
        The model execution time helps testing txtUML models in the following way: when any time-related event inside the model is set to take ms milliseconds, that event will take ms * mul millseconds during model execution, where mul is the current execution time multiplier. This way, txtUML models might be tested at the desired speed.

        Execution time multiplier is 1 by default.

        Parameters:
        newMultiplier - the new execution time multiplier

      • getExecutionTimeMultiplier

        public static float getExecutionTimeMultiplier()
        The model execution time helps testing txtUML models in the following way: when any time-related event inside the model is set to take ms milliseconds, that event will take ms * mul millseconds during model execution, where mul is the current execution time multiplier. This way, txtUML models might be tested at the desired speed.
        Returns:
        the current execution time multiplier
        See Also:
        setExecutionTimeMultiplier(float)

      • inExecutionTime

        public static long inExecutionTime(long time)
        Provides a conversion from 'real time' to model execution time by multiplying its parameter with the execution time multiplier.

        The model execution time helps testing txtUML models in the following way: when any time-related event inside the model is set to take ms milliseconds, that event will take ms * mul millseconds during model execution, where mul is the current execution time multiplier. This way, txtUML models might be tested at the desired speed.

        Execution time multiplier is 1 by default.

        Parameters:
        time - the amount of time to be given in model execution time
        Returns:
        the specified amount of time in model execution time
        See Also:
        setExecutionTimeMultiplier(float)

      • lockExecutionTimeMultiplier

        public static void lockExecutionTimeMultiplier()
        Locks the execution time multiplier so that it may not be changed in the future. It should be called when a time-related event happens in the model to ensure that such events are not influenced by the change of this multiplier in a bad or unspecified way. If called multiple times, this method does nothing after the first call.

        For example, the Timer.start method calls this method as it operates with timed events.
